awd_titl_txt: Coevolution of Aeolian Landscapes and Soils
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will focus on grass-stabilized sand dunes and loess landscapes (areas of thick wind-blown dust deposits) in the Great Plains, to determine how processes that shaped these landscapes in the past will influence their response to future climate change, especially more frequent severe drought or heavy rainfall. The research will test whether soil formation over hundreds to thousands of years, including accumulation of organic matter and fine dust, can significantly reduce the susceptibility of certain parts of these landscapes to wind and water erosion. The results will be important for predicting patterns of future accelerated erosion and dune activation, with major practical implications, since the level tablelands of the loess landscapes are prime agricultural land and the dunes are important rangeland and key recharge areas for the Ogallala Aquifer. Increased erosion could also affect sediment input to streams and release carbon stored in buried and surface soils in these landscapes. The project will provide research training to a diverse group of students and will include development of effective ways to communicate the results to local communities and other stakeholders.

The project will test hypotheses on the interactions between geomorphic processes and soil formation in the evolution of loess tablelands and adjacent dune fields. The hypotheses propose that aeolian processes (deflation, slow loess accumulation, and dune activity) influence spatial patterns of soil formation and organic carbon accumulation, which in turn influence thresholds for wind and water erosion through effects on vegetation resilience and mechanical strength. Study sites will be selected to allow comparison of soil and sediment properties related to nutrient and water availability and shear strength on tableland summits and adjacent slopes with varying soil development and recent loess accumulation, and on dunes with varying soil development. Field and lab measurements will be combined with modeling of soil hydrology, geospatial analyses, and luminescence dating.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we studied the long-term development of aeolian landscapes, formed of loess (wind-blown dust deposits) and dune sand and shaped by both wind and water. We were interested in what we can learn from past development of these landscapes that will help predict how they may change with more frequent droughts and/or extreme rainfall events in the near future, and what the implications are for important land uses and water resources. Our study sites were in western Nebraska in the central Great Plains, but similar landscapes are common in other dry regions of the world. One major focus was on loess tablelands, plateaus that are built up by deposition of dust and have gently sloping tops and steep, gullied margins. On the top of these tablelands, there is often a sequence of soils, formerly at the land surface but then buried by loess, and closed depressions (basins) are also common. The tops of tablelands are usually productive agricultural land, while the side slopes are rangeland.

We hypothesized that the buried soils have increased moisture availability for grassland vegetation and sustain it through droughts, and that the soils are less erodible than the loess they formed in. This hypothesis was not supported by our research using measurements of moisture retention, modeling of soil moisture, and measurements of soil strength. We found that although the soils do retain more water than the loess, that additional water is not easily taken up by plants, so the soils do not increase vegetation resilience during droughts. They do have an impact on deeper redistribution of soil water and may affect groundwater recharge during wet years. At the same moisture content, the soils do not have greater strength than the loess, so they probably are not more resistant to erosion.

Another hypothesis was that the closed depressions on loess tablelands trap runoff water and divert it from the steep gullied slopes, and this was strongly supported by our results. We mapped flow paths of runoff using high-resolution topographic data and found most runoff on the table tops goes into depression, not into gullies. We also used a computer model to simulate long term development of the tablelands with and without closed depressions. Tablelands without depressions eroded faster and were completely destroyed by erosion. However, rapid erosion did occur when gullies broke into large depressions and captured the water that was previously trapped there. We found this process of depression-breaching was common in the past. With more frequent drought and/or more intense rainfall, erosion of loess tablelands will become more rapid. Breaching of depressions by gullies will be especially destructive of productive farmland and could have downstream impacts on water quality.

Finally, we hypothesized that sand dunes in the study area, now almost completely stabilized by vegetation, have accumulated fine dust in their surface soils and this has increased moisture availability to plants. This hypothesis implies that dunes stabilized by grass become even more stable as soils develop and accumulate dust, increasing vegetation resilience during droughts. We found that dune surface soils do accumulate fine material, probably dust, and this dust does increase moisture retention. This effect is noticeable even in dunes that we determined had only been stable for 500-600 years. On the other hand, modeling of soil moisture indicates that the added water retention is not enough to sustain water uptake and growth by grasses during severe modern droughts (2012, for example). Modeling also suggests that the dunes are important sites for groundwater recharge even if better developed soils retain a little more moisture in the surface soil.

Near the end of the project we held a design challenge for students at UW Madison. In this event, 28 students worked in teams to brainstorm and develop ideas on how to visualize and explain the findings of the project, for an audience ranging from residents of our study areas to educators and other scientists. We are now working to convert these ideas into online story maps that will be publicly available and will allow viewers to ask questions on our project and discuss it with us.
